qas.question: What is man always seen as?
What did the English Dominicans like to concentrate on?
What amends humanity to God's life?
The idea of the image of God allows man to do what?
What did French Dominican spirituality concentrate on?
What is man never seen as?

plausible_answers.text: both the ability of man to move toward God (as partakers in Christ's redeeming sacrifice), and that, on some level, man is always an image of God.

qas.question: What does the the "image of God" not demonstrate for man?

plausible_answers.text: the image of God within man becomes ever more bright and clear.

qas.question: What happens when man's love and knowledge of God decreases?

context: Concerning humanity as the image of Christ, English Dominican spirituality concentrated on <b4_0>the <a1_0>moral implications of image-bearing<b4_0/><a1_0/> rather than the philosophical foundations of the imago Dei. <a2_0>The process of Christ's life<a2_0/>, and the process of image-bearing, amends humanity to God's image. The idea of the "<b5_0>image of God<b5_0/>" demonstrates <b6_0>both the ability of man to <a3_0>move toward God<a3_0/> (as partakers in Christ's redeeming sacrifice), and that, on some level, man is always <a0_0>an image of God<a0_0/>.<b6_0/> As their love and knowledge of God grows and is sanctified by faith and experience, <b7_0>the image of God within man becomes ever more bright and clear.
